results.headline: Review: ‘Lost in Hong Kong’ Is Part Music Video, Part Buddy Film
results.summary_short: Xu Zheng directs and stars in this comedy about a former art student who seeks to shed his brother-in-law so he can reunite with a woman from his past.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lost In Hong Kong

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Keeping Room,’ 3 Women Under Siege in the Civil War
results.summary_short: The British director Daniel Barber labors to impress in this Southern period thriller with two Union soldiers preying on two sisters and a slave.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Keeping Room

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Green Inferno,’ Eli Roth Turns Collegians Into Prey
results.summary_short: This film, set in the Peruvian Amazon, revisits the cannibal subgenre whose heyday was in the 1970s and ’80s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Green Inferno

results.headline: Review: In ‘Sleepless in New York,’ the Misery of the Lovelorn
results.summary_short: This documentary introduces three city dwellers who are reeling from breakups, with general commentary on lovesickness from a biological anthropologist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sleepless in New York

results.headline: Review: In ‘Pay the Ghost,’ Nicolas Cage Is on a Mission
results.summary_short: In this film, Mr. Cage’s character searches for his son after the boy is abducted at a Halloween carnival.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pay the Ghost

results.headline: Review: In ‘Misunderstood,’ a Girl Seeks Relief From a Turbulent Household
results.summary_short: Asia Argento’s somewhat autobiographical film wavers between realism and surrealism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Misunderstood

results.headline: Review: In ‘Hotel Transylvania 2,’ Dracula Yearns for a Little Monster of a Grandson
results.summary_short: In this sequel, Dracula’s daughter has married a human and begotten a son, and her father worries that the boy may not be vampirish enough.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hotel Transylvania 2

results.headline: Review: ‘Becoming Bulletproof’ Follows a Group of Disabled Adults in a Film Within a Film
results.summary_short: Besides the usual ordeals of moviemaking — missed lines, bad cues — Michael Barnett, the documentary’s director, looked at the cast and crew’s friendships and struggles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Becoming Bulletproof

results.headline: Review: ‘Ashby’ Pairs a Retired C.I.A. Killer With a High School Nerd
results.summary_short: Mickey Rourke stars as the former assassin and Nat Wolff as the student who wants to hear his life story in this semicomic film from Tony McNamara.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ashby

results.display_title: A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story
results.headline: Review: ‘A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story,’ One Woman’s Push for Acceptance
results.summary_short: Sara Hirsh Bordo, directing her first feature, keeps the scenes bright and fast-moving, but several important topics about Ms. Velasquez are are barely addressed.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story

results.headline: Review: ‘Stonewall’ Doesn’t Distinguish Between Facts and Fiction
results.summary_short: Roland Emmerich’s film wants to be as specific as possible in reconstructing the Stonewall riots, but it also wants to be sweeping social allegory.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stonewall

results.headline: Review: ‘Uncle John’ Is Steeped in Secrets
results.summary_short: The first feature from Steven Piet unfolds with murkiness and ambiguity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Uncle John

results.display_title: The Man Who Saved the World
results.headline: Review: ‘The Man Who Saved the World’ Recounts a Cold War Near Miss
results.summary_short: This hybrid documentary centers on the life of Lt. Col. Stanislav Petrov, who was in charge of the Soviet early warning systems overnight on Sept. 26, 1983.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Man Who Saved the World

results.headline: Review: ‘Racing Extinction’ Charts the Slaughter of Vital Species
results.summary_short: From the makers of “The Cove,” this documentary centers on the slaughter of creatures for profit without regard for the environmental consequences.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Racing Extinction

results.headline: Review: In ‘Veteran,’ an ’80s Cop Comedy Vibe From South Korea
results.summary_short: The film follows an honest detective taking on the pampered, sociopathic heir to a family-owned business conglomerate.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Veteran

results.headline: Review: In ‘The New Girlfriend,’ a Widower’s Secret Life Is Revealed
results.summary_short: The director François Ozon offers a serio-comic exploration of cross-dressing, gender fluidity and desire in his adaptation of a dark story by Ruth Rendell.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The New Girlfriend

results.headline: Review: In ‘Office’ by Johnnie To, Ups and Downs of Business
results.summary_short: Set after Lehman Brothers’ collapse, Mr. To’s film, starring Chow Yun Fat and Sylvia Chang, looks at the clash between public lies and private lives.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Office

results.headline: Review: ‘Songs From the North’ Works to Understand a People and Their Country
results.summary_short: The director Soon-Mi Yoo looks to penetrate presumptions of North Korea in this film, a personal essay built on three trips she took to the nation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Songs from the North

results.headline: Review: ‘Some Kind of Hate,’ a Bullying-Revenge Slasher Tale
results.summary_short: The blood flows and flows in this horror thriller, featuring Ronen Rubinstein and Sierra McCormick as two kids — one of them’s dead — trying to get back at their tormentors.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Some Kind of Hate

results.headline: Review: ‘Sicario’ Digs Into the Depths of Drug Cartel Violence
results.summary_short: Denis Villeneuve’s new movie, which stars Emily Blunt and Josh Brolin, tries to paint a morally complicated picture instead of restaging a morality play.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sicario
